en.template: The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɑ/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɑ/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /o/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ always carries stress and sounds like /o/.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /u/ and does not reduce, regardless of stress.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /u/ and does not reduce, regardless of stress.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like [ɨ] and does not change with stress.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɛ/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɛ/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /i/ and never reduces in sung Russian.
The soft sign has no sound of its own. It palatalizes the consonant before it.
The hard sign has no sound of its own. It keeps the preceding consonant hard and signals a /j/ glide before the next vowel.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /b/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /v/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɡ/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /d/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /ʒ/ and is always hard.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /z/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ is a semivowel, sounding like the glide /j/.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /k/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɫ/ when hard, a distinctly Russian sound.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /m/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /n/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /p/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ is always trilled in sung Russian, sounding like /r/.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /s/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /t/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /f/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /x/ in sung Russian.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /ts/ and is always hard.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /tʃʲ/ and is always soft.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /ʃ/ and is always hard.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /ʃʲʃʲ/ and is always soft.
(Grayson, {pages})
